There is already a huge chill in FDI. If Russia goes further and begins seizing the assets of foreign companies, it will expose state-owned (and possibly privately owned) Russian companies operating abroad to similar sanctions. For an oil exporter, it will be an unmitigated disaster.

The article discusses the new law as if Russia were immunizing itself from the effects of sanctions, but that is far from true. If Russia begins seizing the assets of foreign companies, there will be a huge chill in foreign direct investment (as Ulyukayev alluded to), which will exacerbate the economy's slowdown. Russia will basically be shooting itself in the foot.

On another note, the article does not indicate whether the law is consistent with Russia's WTO obligations. Addressing that issue would have greatly improved the article.

Coal is not the problem. Burning it as fuel is the problem.

Even if somehow magically "clean" burning it is a CO2 problem.

Like any other carbon fuels, petroleum and gas, coal can be converted to other things. It can be used, instead of burned for fuel. It can be used instead of the oil and gas obtained by fracking, and so with less damage to the envirnment that fracking (a lesser evil argument).

It can also be fuel without traditional burning. For one example, a direxct carbon fuel cell, while technically oxidizing carbon, does it far more efficiently and in a way that makes it easy to capture the CO2. Coal could do that.

For coal, gas, oil, fracking, global warming, all of it, the best answer is the same: develop the alternative technologies to produce energy and products.

That isn't a mere cost, it is a profit opportunity, and the only way to the long term future anyway as world economic growth exceeds traditional energy sources.

We'll have to do it anyway. Whether we do it now, or wait until we're under water and our temperatures and rainfall changed, it is only a question of when we do it, not if we must do it.

Just to clarify something. The article discussed deficits but keep in mind that accumulated deficits just add to debt. Our national debt is now about $17.8 trillion or over 100% of GDP. http://www.usdebtclock.org/#

And that doesn't come close to describing the problem. We've made future obligations in the form of pensions, social security, medicare, etc. (And in case anyone still believes there is a pot of money into which your SS and medicare contributions have been waiting for you, I've got a bridge to sell you.)

According to the Medicare Trustees, the accumulated deficit for Medicare (after offsetting Medicare taxes) is another $42 trillion. Add in the analogous deficit for Social Security is another $20 trillion. Add it all up and it's $86.8 trillion debt or over 550% of GDP !
